stream_context.summary: Kaze redesigns and implements the overworld entrance to the Zoo/Wario’s Wildlife World, replacing an overcomplicated ticket/penguin concept with a crawlspace-based gate. He prototypes new entrance geometry, adds a warp trigger to transition into the Zoo, programs Wario as a physical “goalkeeper” NPC that blocks jumping past the gate, and fixes an engine bug where cutscene flags were written to the wrong course/slot.
stream_context.significance_reason: A key overworld progression mechanic is locked in (crawlspace entry + Wario blocker + warp transition), and a non-trivial engine bug affecting cutscene flags across courses is discovered and fixed.

findings.summary: Kaze abandons the earlier Zoo entrance concept (Wario charging coins equal to your coins+1 plus a ticket-penguin side objective) because it feels overly complicated, random, and inelegant for an overworld gate.

He converges on a new entrance solution: a visible crawlspace/tunnel that lets the player slip into the Zoo, paired with Wario physically blocking the main gate so the objective is clear and diegetic rather than menu- or item-driven.

To make crawlspaces readable, he plans explicit environmental cues (coin trail leading into the hole, potentially a mouse NPC going in/out, and improving floor visibility/contrast inside the tunnel) rather than adding a journal/tutorial prompt.

He intentionally allows a skill-based bypass: if players (or speedrunners) can manage to jump/clip around Wario or exploit movement velocity, he’s okay with them entering without crawling, as an emergent high-skill alternative.

Kaze implements an overworld warp volume near the Zoo gate so approaching the entrance cleanly transitions the player to the correct Zoo spawn/warp ID, effectively making the gate area a controlled ‘warp zone.’

He programs Wario as an active blocker NPC who tracks Mario laterally and prevents jumping over/around the gate, then adds safeguards to prevent Wario from pushing the player into walls (including adjusting collision response and adding an invisible blocking plane).

A core engine bug is identified: during cutscenes, the game wrote the cutscene/‘entered level’ flag to the wrong course slot, so Wario wouldn’t disappear after the first Zoo visit. Fixing this restores correct per-course persistence behavior.
findings.quote: There was a bug all along in the engine, where if you were watching a cutscene, it would set the cutscene flag in the wrong place.

findings.summary: Kaze relates the cutscene-flag issue to a known vanilla SM64 quirk (opening a cannon in Bob-omb Battlefield can set a cannon flag in another level), implying he’s rebuilding or replacing similar global-flag indexing behavior in his decomp-based framework.

He notes ongoing engine instability: a collision issue sometimes allows phasing through geometry, which he frames as “equally annoying as invisible walls,” and he wants it fixed as part of making traversal feel fair.
He calls out production constraints: the Zoo entrance area is already ~29,000 triangles before collision is finished, signaling that triangle/geo budgeting is becoming a real consideration.
He states remaining “engine rework” tasks before full content production freedom: operating system work and collision BVH (which he also ties to future plans like AI training needing BVH for speed).
Kaze expects Biobak to rework parts of the overworld/entrance visually later; for now he prioritizes gameplay functionality and blockers over final art polish.

He mentions Sauraen’s new F3DEX3 update yields a small RSP-time performance win (on the order of ~100–200 microseconds), reinforcing that the project is still collecting micro-optimizations where possible.

Kaze shares unusually candid anxiety about filing taxes as a self-employed creator, describing stress and reduced ability to think clearly despite believing his filings are correct; he links this to having “more to lose” after becoming a parent.

He states a strong design aversion to cosmetic-only rewards, citing negative experiences in Tears of the Kingdom where cosmetic chest rewards felt like wasted player time; he prefers rewards to be functional or optional/out-of-the-way.
findings.quote: I hate cosmetics in video games.

biobak.summary: Kaze describes Biobak as responsible for visual reworks of the area later, and as a source of additional Wario animations/moves as needed (Kaze implements behavior logic; Biobak expands the animation set).
biobak.quote: Biobak does that for me. He can make more and more of Wario's moves.

findings.summary: Kaze reports Sauraen pushed an F3DEX3 update the same day, improving RSP performance by roughly ~100–200 microseconds; once integrated into Fast64, it should save small but meaningful time.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There was a bug all along in the engine, where if you were watching a cutscene, it would set the cutscene flag in the wrong place.
memorable_quotes.context: He realizes why Wario didn’t disappear after the first Zoo visit and ties the fix to correctness of persistent overworld gating.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I hate cosmetics in video games.
memorable_quotes.context: A strong, values-driven stance that reflects how he thinks about rewards, respect for player time, and what he does not want RTYI to become.

key_stories.title: Replacing the Zoo ticket quest with a crawlspace gate
key_stories.summary: Kaze evaluates the planned Zoo entrance quest (coin-gated ticket pricing plus a penguin ticket subplot) and decides it’s too messy and arbitrary for the overworld. He pivots to a more physical, readable gate: Wario blocks the main entrance, while a crawl tunnel provides the intended entry route.
key_stories.challenge: The original entrance logic felt complicated, inelegant, and tonally random, risking player confusion for a core overworld progression step.
key_stories.process: He brainstorms alternatives (open entrance, coin booth, secret entrance), lands on a crawlspace, iterates entrance geometry, and plans environmental affordances (coin trail, mice) to teach the mechanic without explicit tutorials.
key_stories.outcome: A new gate design is implemented and tested: warp trigger into the Zoo + crawlspace plan + Wario as an in-world blocker; the area is now ready for later polish and signposting.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't want that because I think that's too over complicated and there's just too much shit happening there.

key_stories.title: Cutscene persistence bug prevents Wario from disappearing
key_stories.summary: After implementing a ‘Wario disappears once you’ve entered the Zoo’ rule, Kaze finds it doesn’t work even after watching the intro cutscene and dying. He traces the issue to a cutscene flag being stored in the wrong course index/slot during cutscenes—similar to a known SM64 cannon flag bug—and fixes the engine logic.
key_stories.challenge: Progress-state persistence (whether the player has ‘officially been in the Zoo’) was incorrect, breaking the intended one-time gate behavior.
key_stories.process: He reproduces the issue in-game, inspects the star/flag bits, notices a type/size mismatch (U8 vs S16) and indexing anomalies, then identifies that cutscenes write flags to the wrong place.
key_stories.outcome: Wario correctly disappears after the first Zoo visit, validating both the new entrance flow and the underlying save/flag logic.
key_stories.key_quote: There was a bug all along in the engine, where if you were watching a cutscene, it would set the cutscene flag in the wrong place.

key_stories.title: Anxiety spike over self-employment taxes while building the game
key_stories.summary: Mid-stream, Kaze derails into a candid account of being unusually nervous about taxes despite believing everything is correct. He attributes the intensity to being self-employed and having ‘more to lose,’ especially after having a child.
key_stories.challenge: Background life stress disrupts focus and confidence during technical problem-solving.
key_stories.process: He talks it out live, acknowledges the fear is disproportionate, and continues working while describing his mental fog.
key_stories.outcome: The stream documents the emotional load behind sustained indie development—especially when the creator’s personal responsibilities increase.
key_stories.key_quote: My brain is so nerfed from the stress of the taxes that are like 99% correct that it is fucking me up.

open_questions.topic: Final intended ‘teaching’ of crawlspaces in the overworld
open_questions.context: Kaze decides against a journal/tutorial prompt and instead plans environmental cues (coin trail, possibly mice) to communicate crawlspaces as a mechanic.
questions: Where is the first crawlspace in the intended player route, and what is the earliest moment you expect players to learn crawling?
Did playtesting ever show players missing crawl tunnels, and what signals (coins, NPC movement, lighting, floor color) proved most effective?
Are crawlspaces meant to be a recurring ‘language’ in the overworld (secret routing), or mostly a one-off gate solution here?

open_questions.topic: Design intent behind allowing a skill-based bypass of Wario
open_questions.context: Kaze expresses openness to speedrunners entering the Zoo without crawling if they can pull it off, while also noting current movement can generate excessive velocity.
questions: What kinds of ‘sequence breaks’ do you consider healthy for RTYI, and where do you draw the line between fun tech and broken routing?
Will you intentionally preserve at least one hard bypass route here as a reward for mastery, or will it depend on whether it destabilizes other systems?
How will you tune movement/velocity so bypassing is skillful rather than accidental jank?

open_questions.topic: Cutscene flag indexing and persistence architecture
open_questions.context: A cutscene wrote the ‘entered level’ flag to the wrong course slot, reminiscent of vanilla SM64 cannon flag misindexing; Kaze fixes it after Wario fails to disappear.
questions: What is your new persistence model for RTYI (entered-level flags, cutscene flags, star bits), and how does it differ from vanilla SM64’s quirks?
How did this bug survive until now—was it masked by earlier content not relying on ‘first visit’ logic?
Are there other known ‘global flag index’ hazards still in the engine that could cause cross-level side effects?

open_questions.topic: Collision reliability and the ‘phasing through geometry’ regression
open_questions.context: Kaze flags a current engine issue where the player can sometimes phase through collision, and he frames collision correctness as difficult but essential.
questions: What changed that made phasing appear (new collision representation, numerical precision, broadphase changes, BVH work-in-progress)?
How do you test collision correctness on real hardware versus emulator, and what ‘worst case’ scenarios are you designing against?
Do you expect the collision BVH rewrite to fix phasing directly, or is BVH mainly a performance enabler while correctness needs separate constraints?

open_questions.topic: Wario NPC: animation needs and behavioral ‘feel’ targets
open_questions.context: Kaze uses existing animations as stand-ins (even repurposing a non-jump animation) and plans a shuffle animation; he also adjusts turning logic and wall-response to keep Wario centered and non-janky.
questions: What was your target ‘vibe’ for Wario here (Mido-like gatekeeper, comedic annoyance, morally gray bouncer), and how did that shape the behavior tuning?
What specific animations did you request from Biobak for Wario to sell the blocking behavior (shuffle, hop, laugh, taunt), and what’s still missing?
How did you balance physical blocking (hitboxes, invisible planes) against player frustration when returning to the gate repeatedly?
